Parts.Content: Part 1 - Read the email from Anie to her friend. Choose one word from the list for each gap. The first one is done for you.

Questions.Content:
Dear Sunny,
How’s everything going? Love to 0. (hear) from you!
I’ve been busy these days with my school. Everyone is 1. (friendly/ melty/ noisy)
I can 2. (train/ sleep/ walk) to my class.
I met a wonderful friend for the 3. (very/ first/ one) time.
She can 4. (talk/ say/ speak) five languages.
We should eat dinner 5. (toward/ together/ another). Hope to see you soon!
Love,
Anie

AnswerContent.content:
Everyone is 1. ……… | A. friendly / B. melty / C. noisy
I can 2. ……… to my class. | A. train / B. sleep / C. walk
I met a wonderful friend for the 3. ……… time. | A. very / B. first / C. one
She can 4. ……… five languages. | A. talk / B. say / C. speak
We should eat dinner 5. ……… | A. toward / B. together / C. another

Parts.Content: Part 2A: The sentences below are an instruction about a history centre. Put the sentences in the right order. The first sentence is done for you.
Parts.SubContent: Example: Let's discover the amazing tourist attractions here.

Questions.Content: Let's discover the amazing tourist attractions here.

AnswerContent.content:
A. The most important of these is the Natural History Centre.
B. When you enter the building from the square, you will see a set of stairs to your left.
C. The ticket office is on the top of these stairs, the staff there are very helpful.
D. The entrance of the centre is on the town's main square.
E. As well as selling tickets, they can provide maps and useful tour information.

Parts.Content: Part 2B: The sentences below are a story about Tom Harper. Put the sentences in the right order. The first sentence is done for you.
Parts.SubContent: Example: Tom Harper was a wonderful person.

Questions.Content: Tom Harper was a wonderful person.

AnswerContent.content:
A. When he was young, he began writing short stories for a magazine.
B. He almost left the magazine, but then he decided to create some unusual new characters.
C. The characters he imagined were one of the most famous in the world.
D. He soon wrote regularly for the magazine, but he was not satisfied.
E. This popularity made Tom Harper rich and successful.

Parts.Content: Part 3: Four people respond in the comments section of an online magazine article about volunteering to clean a local park. Read the texts and then answer the questions below.

Questions.Content:
Henry
I feel very lucky to have this park here. My family and I often go to the park because of the natural landscape here. It's different from the city, which is very busy and full of dust. Unfortunately, I am away this weekend so I cannot help with the cleaning. However, I know my brother and his friends will be very interested in this cleanup so I will ask them if they can help.
Sam
I'm a very busy person and I have to spend this weekend with my family because I only have the weekend as free time. I think young people who don't have families should help. Besides, students and schools also have days off on weekends. I think this volunteering will be very helpful for students' future careers. 
Paul
I think this volunteering is a good idea but it doesn't have a long-term vision. When volunteers clean up the park, it will be clean, but it will become busy again after about a month when tourist season arrives. I think we should clean this park regularly about once a month. Surrounding areas such as the lake and local forest should also be cleaned up. We should also have signs telling visitors to clean up their trash. I am very upset when I see a lot of trash on both sides of the road. 
Linda
My family and I often spend time at the park. My children love going to the park and they find the park a very interesting place to visit. My son has a dream of becoming a biologist so I think cleaning up this park will be very helpful for my son. I think we should pique children's interest in cleaning. They will be more willing to volunteer and help others.

AnswerContent.content:
1. Who thinks the park is a beautiful place to relax? | A. Henry / B. Sam / C. Paul / D. Linda
2. Who thinks volunteering will help with future employment? | A. Henry / B. Sam / C. Paul / D. Linda
3. Who thinks local areas need cleaning? | A. Henry / B. Sam / C. Paul / D. Linda
4. Who will ask for others to help? | A. Henry / B. Sam / C. Paul / D. Linda
5. Who can't clean the park because of their busy work? | A. Henry / B. Sam / C. Paul / D. Linda
6. Who thinks the cleaning needs to be done regularly? | A. Henry / B. Sam / C. Paul / D. Linda
7. Who thinks volunteering is important for students? | A. Henry / B. Sam / C. Paul / D. Linda

Parts.Content: Part 4 - Read the following passage quickly. Choose a heading for each numbered paragraph (1-7). There is one more heading than you need.

Questions.Content:
Early Australia
Paragraph 1 - The traditional view of Australia’s history begins with the arrival of British settlers in 1788, but Australia’s history started long before then. Indigenous Australians, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, have lived on the continent for over 65,000 years. They are believed to have migrated from Southeast Asia, possibly by navigating land bridges and seas. These early settlers developed rich cultures, languages, and strong connections to the land. Acknowledging this alternative history broadens our understanding of Australia’s past and highlights the significance of Indigenous contributions to the country’s heritage. 
Paragraph 2 - Australia’s remote location and harsh environment created a natural barrier to early migration and settlement. Surrounded by vast oceans and featuring rugged terrain, deserts, and unique ecosystems, the continent was difficult to reach and explore. Early explorers and settlers faced limited water sources, extreme weather, and unfamiliar wildlife, which made survival challenging. Even after British settlers arrived, the harsh landscape slowed the spread of colonies across Australia. The land’s challenging conditions required people to adapt and develop special survival skills.
Paragraph 3 - Modern technology has provided tools to study the early migration routes to Australia. Underwater archaeology, sonar mapping, and satellite imaging have uncovered ancient sites and artifacts, offering clues about the pathways early humans took. These tools allow researchers to explore underwater regions that were once dry land, revealing potential routes and sites where early humans may have stopped along the way. Such discoveries are helping scientists understand more about how the first people arrived in Australia and the resources they used.
Paragraph 4 - Early migration to Australia was likely a long and challenging journey made in stages. Researchers believe that ancient people traveled from Southeast Asia to Australia by crossing islands, taking breaks between stages of their journey. Each stage would have involved adapting to new environments, finding food and water, and developing navigation skills. This gradual journey highlights the determination and resilience of early humans as they moved across unknown territories, ultimately reaching Australia. Such staged migration required planning, adaptability, and survival skills that helped them face the challenges of each new stage.
Paragraph 5 - Recent archaeological finds in Australia and Southeast Asia are leading scientists to speculate about early human arrival. Discoveries of ancient tools and fossils suggest humans might have arrived even earlier than previously thought. These findings push back the estimated timeline of human migration to Australia and raise questions about how early communities lived and traveled. Each new discovery helps form a clearer picture of the past, but also introduces new mysteries, allowing researchers to consider different theories and possibilities about the lives of these ancient travelers.
Paragraph 6 - European settlers arriving in Australia lacked the skills and knowledge to survive in its unique environment. Unlike Indigenous Australians, who had lived on the land for thousands of years and understood it well, the newcomers struggled to find food, water, and shelter. They were unfamiliar with the climate, wildlife, and local plants, which made survival difficult. Many settlers depended on Indigenous knowledge to learn how to live in the environment, but the initial lack of skills led to hardship and failed expeditions. This highlights the importance of understanding and respecting the local environment.
Paragraph 7 - Explorers have shown remarkable determination to map and understand Australia’s vast lands. Indigenous Australians journeyed across the continent, developing deep connections to the land, while European explorers in the 18th and 19th centuries were driven by curiosity and ambition. Explorers like James Cook, Matthew Flinders, and Burke and Wills took risks to explore unknown areas, often facing dangerous conditions. Their determination, though sometimes costly, paved the way for new settlements and trade. The spirit of exploration continues to inspire Australians to discover more about their unique land.

AnswerContent.content:
Contents:
1. Paragraph 1
2. Paragraph 2
3. Paragraph 3
4. Paragraph 4 
5. Paragraph 5
6. Paragraph 6
7. Paragraph 7
Options:
A. Technology helps uncover the ocean's secret
B. A new evidence that leads to speculation
C. Determination of the explorers through the ages
D. An alternative history of settlement
E. A journey made by stages
F. Changing perspectives on Australia's past
G. Natural barrier to resettlement 
H. Lack of knowledge and skills

Parts.Content: Part 1: You want to join the Walking Club. You have 5 messages from a member of the club. Write short answers (1 – 5 words) to each message. Recommended time: 3 minutes.

Questions.Content: How is the weather today?
What is your favorite season of the year?
What do you usually do in your free time?
What is your favorite sport?
What is a place you would like to visit in your country?

Parts.Content: Part 2: You are a new member of the Walking Club. Fill in the form. Write in sentences. Use 20-30 words. Recommended time: 7 minutes.

Questions.Content: Please tell us the last time you went for a walk.

Parts.Content: Part 3: You are a member of the Walking Club. You are talking to other members in a chat room. Reply to their questions. Write in sentences. Use 30-40 words per answer. Recommended time: 10 minutes.

Questions.Content: Lim: I often go for a walk in the park at night. What about you?
Henry: I prefer to go to the countryside for a walk. Walking in the city is stressful and noisy. What do you think?
Sophie: In the past, people walked long distances as part of their lives. These days, they don't walk anymore. Why?

Parts.Content: Part 4: You are a member of the Walking Club. You have received this email from the club manager.
Parts.SubContent:
Dear Member,
Nowadays, many people use their phones while walking so they don't focus on walking. This leads to many dangerous issues for our society. Therefore, our club wants all members to make suggestions on this issue.
The Manager

Questions.Content: Write an email to your friend who is also a member of the club. Write about your feelings and what you would like to do. Write about 50 words. Recommended time: 10 minutes
Write an email to the manager of the club. Write about your feelings and what you think the club should do about the situation. Write about 120-150 words. Recommended time: 20 minutes.
What did you do yesterday?
Please tell me about your friends.
Please tell me about your favorite film.
Describe the picture.
What kind of things do you enjoy reading?
Why do people enjoy reading books?
Describe two pictures.
What are some benefits of shopping in these two places?
Where do you think people will shop in the future?
Tell me about a time when you tried hard to achieve something.
How do you feel when you succeed?
How can people be encouraged to achieve hard things?
